Text: #TBT - One year ago the House passed the 21st Century Cures Act, a law that makes government an ally, rather than an obstacle, in the cycle of medical innovation. Today #SubHealth will hear from leaders at the helm of its implementation. Watch here:https://energycommerce.house.gov/hearings/implementing-21st-century-cures-act-update-fda-nih/ …
As we take time to reflect on another year’s blessings, I wish you and your family a happy and safe Thanksgiving.pic.twitter.com/thZkBmk5u9

Yesterday the House passed a major tax reform package for the first time since 1986. Today's weekly address breaks down several ways these reforms will help hardworking families here in North Texas.https://youtu.be/gG-COueL034

One key insight from my teletown hall last night: Of the 26th District constituents who were dialed and chose to participate, more than half support the repeal of Obamacare's individual mandate.pic.twitter.com/org5vylLuU

Last night I held a teletown hall with almost 2,500 constituents from the 26th District to hear your concerns and ideas about tax reform. Thank you to those who took the time to join. As always, I value your input on this issue and every other issue that comes before the House.pic.twitter.com/vakzzpbltM

The Pentagon should be held to the same level of accountability as other federal agencies when it comes to spending taxpayer dollars. My Audit the Pentagon amendment, included in the NDAA for Fiscal Year 2018, is a key measure for fiscal responsibility. http://bit.ly/2zYupJo pic.twitter.com/qhETDkln3V

Amarillo lost 28 physicians in the two years preceding reforms. Since reforms, Amarillo has gained 75 physicians.
Because of liability reform, the ranks of high risk specialists have grown more than twice as fast as the state’s population.
Because of liability reform, 50 counties that did not have an emergency medicine physician’s now do. 38 of those counties are rural.
Thanks to liability reform 36% of Texas doctors are accepting more high risk patients.
These medical liability changes have had incredibly positive effects on medical care in Texas
10 Years ago today, Texas voters approved sweeping liability reforms that ensured Texans' access to high-quality medical care.

Participatory democracy is alive and well in the US. Now the next chapter will be written. It remains to be seen if members have listened.
